metadata.title: High attack rate of SARS-CoV-2 infections during a bus tour in Japan

body_text.text: It is critical to prevent and control tour-related coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreaks for the travel industry. Although airplane-or bus-related COVID-19 outbreaks were reported in several countries, the evidence on severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) transmission in vehicles is limited. 1-3 Here, we report the findings from an investigation of a COVID-19 outbreak occurring following a 4day tour on four buses visited 11 tourist sites around Hokkaido, Japan, in October 2020. The total number of people on the bus tour was 158 (146 participants and 12 staff members): 41 for Bus 1, 39 for Bus 2, 40 for Bus 3 and 38 for Bus 4.

A participant on Bus 1 (primary case) was diagnosed as having COVID-19 because of a fever after the tour. The remaining 37 passengers and three staff members on Bus 1 were tested and their health status was monitored for 14 days after the tour. Those who used Buses 2-4, the staff of the hotels in which the participants stayed, and family members and close friends of the confirmed case were also asked to check their health status after the last exposure. Tests were conducted once and again thereafter if they developed symptoms. We collected information on the health status of all tour participants and close contacts, details of the tour from the local governments and the travel agency and the results of whole genome sequence of some isolates that we could analyze. Relative risk (RR) according to seating positions on the bus was calculated along with the 95% confidence interval (CI). This study was exempt from the requirement for institutional ethics review as it was part of a public health control measures under the Infectious Diseases Control Law in Japan.

We years, and 10 participants were female (53%). Although one participant required mechanical ventilation, there were no fatalities. Except for the primary case, all but one were exposed to other confirmed cases only during the bus tour within 14 days before symptom onset or specimen collection.

Among the 38 participants in Bus 1, four were single tourists (11%), 28 joined as pairs (74%) and six were parties of three (16%). The total driving times per day were 3.5, 7, 6 and 2 h on Days 1-4, respectively. The continuous driving time was 53 min on average, and the longest driving minutes was 115 min on Day 3. The participants did not get involved in group activities in the hotels but ate breakfast and dinner with group members in the restaurants. They spent most of the time on the bus while wearing masks except when they ate or drank. Bus seats were assigned to each group daily. Body temperature was measured only at the start of the tour and at hotel check-in, but no record was kept. Seating of the cases showed clustering around the primary case on Days 2 and 3 and was grouped in a front-to-back direction ( Figure 1 ). Closeness of seating to the primary case showed that six cases were separated by 3 or 4 rows, and 10 non-infected cases were in the same or a 1-row different position. RRs increased according to the closeness to the primary case ( Table 1 ). The RRs were significantly high on the same side from two rows to six rows on Days 2 and 3 (Table 1) . However, the 2-row rule (within two rows and on both [right/left] sides of the primary case) 4 or the distance from the primary case cannot fully explain many cases.

The air conditioning system in these buses takes in fresh air from the front of the vehicle and then discharges it mainly from around the rear seat ceiling. Therefore, air flowed from the front to back when the bus windows were closed. During breaks, the bus air conditioning was turned off, and the windows were not always open. Some participants remained on the bus during breaks. Frequent announcements about wearing masks and hand hygiene were made throughout the tour.

Three family members and relatives whom the primary case visited 2 days before the tour were confirmed to have COVID-19. Genome analysis of the four cases including the primary case revealed that one isolate (GISAID ID: EPI_ISL_1128776) was identical with and the other two isolates (EPI_ISL_898608 and EPI_ISL_ 901 504) had one base different from that of the primary case (EPI_ISL_1128775).

The long hours spent in a confined bus and the low opportunity to participate in other group activities suggested that SARS-CoV-2 transmission occurred on the bus. Universal mask wearing fits the usual practice of Japanese, who are used to wearing masks during the winter season, and will reduce the risk of transmission, but droplet transmission could occur while eating snacks or drinking on the bus. Other possible routes of transmission were indirect contact transmission following suboptimal hand hygiene or airborne transmission due to poor bus ventilation. The tour staff emphasized hand hygiene, but how strictly the participants followed this guidance was unclear. Further, the participants were mostly older people who tend to use handrails, 5 which were not frequently cleaned and disinfected during the tour.

Despite frequent announcements about wearing masks and hand hygiene, we observed a high AR. This is likely due to the nature of the bus tour, which has a high density of passengers, 6 narrow space, long-duration, poor ventilation and difficulty in wearing proper masks and hand hygiene under these conditions. The bus tour is not just a means of transportation, but it is part of a leisure and passengers enjoyed the scenery, sightseeing spots and food while eating and drinking during tour. High population density is considered to affect reproductive numbers. 6 On the other hand, in circumstances such as high population densities, 6 longduration contact and poor ventilation, airborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2 could occur. 7 Possible airborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in a vehicle has also been reported. 1,2 ,8 Infection in a front-to-back direction following the airflow in the bus in this study supported this hypothesis. Based on this outbreak and other experience, 9,10 the travel agency introduced a system to check the health status of participants and staff on-site and at their headquarters, restrict ill persons from participation, shorten continuous driving times, keep the air conditioning on continuously at all times during the tour, clean and disinfect the environment inside at each stop and prohibit eating and allow only drinking during the bus tour.

The bus tour related COVID-19 outbreak showed high AR in the bus. Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 can occur during a bus tour possibly by airborne transmission or indirect contact transmission. Bus tour companies need to ensure hand hygiene of participants and staff and provide effective ventilation in the bus.
